attributes.title: Pronto Study: Partnerships for Post-Overdose Outreach

summary.value: This is an analytic plan registration for the Pronto Study: Partnerships for Post-Overdose Outreach. In specific, the registration details Pronto Study's first aim - a statewide inventory of post-overdose outreach programs in Massachusetts. The registration document (attached) details the analytic plan of the statewide inventory of post-overdose outreach programs.

q1.value: Intentionality, speaker’s attitude and the processing of verbal irony

q2.value: Camilo Rodriguez Ronderos, Ira Andrew Noveck, John Michael Tomlinson Jr

q3.value:
The literature on irony processing has often looked at whether ironic sentences are easier, just as easy, or harder to understand than equivalent literal sentences, resulting in mixed findings. 
In this study, we investigate how information about a speaker's attitude towards an upcoming utterance and expectational biases about the answer to a polar question influence reading times of sentences that are understood either ironically or literally. 
By doing this we wish to investigate whether these two factors can modulate reading times of ironic and literal sentences and help explain why their respective reading speed varies.
The study is thus a 2X2 repeated-measures experiment with the factors Speaker's Attitude (sincere vs. insincere) and expectaitonal bias type (zero bias vs negative bias).
The present experiment is a direct replication of a previous study conducted by the authors: The only change made is the number of participants tested. The current number of participants was determined via simulations using the previous data as the starting point.

q4.value:
We have 3 sets of hypotheses: 

1. answers to comprehension questions: Participants should overall understand a speaker's insincere attitude towards an upcoming sentence as a reliable cue for ironic intent, as indicated by the answer to the comprehension questions in the critical trials. This should translate to an effect of speaker's attitude on the answers to comprehension questions, with answers in the sincere condition being moslty indicative of a literal understanding of the target sentence and answers in the insincere condition showing an ironic understanding of the target sentence. 

2. Reading times: Our main hypothesis is that we should should find a significant interaction between the two factors, such that the insincere-negative bias reading times are shorter than the insincere-zero bias reading times, and the sincere-zero bias reading times are shorter than the sincere-negative bias reading times. This interaction effect should appear in a model using sum-contrast coding.

3. Reading times: Additionally, in a model of the same data using a slider-contrast coding, we make specific predictions regarding the differences between the individual conditions. We predict that:

1. The insincere-zero bias condition will show significantly longer reading times than the insincere-negative bias
2. The sincere-negative bias condition will show significantly longer reading times than the sincere-zero bias condition
3. The reading times in the insincere-negative bias condition will not be significantly different than the reading times in the sincere-zero bias condition
4. The sincere-zero bias will show significantly shorter reading times than the insincere-zero bias condition
5. the insincere-negative bias condition will show significantly shorter reading times than the sincere-negative bias condition

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The experiment has a repeated measures, latin-square 2X2 design (every participants sees every item but only in one condition and every participant sees every condition at least once) with the factors Expectation Bias (zero vs. negative expectation bias) and Speaker’s Attitude (sincere vs. insincere attitude). There are 4 experimental lists that participants can be assigned to.

q9.value: The order of presentation of critical and filler sentences is randomized for every participant. The assignment of participants to indivual lists is randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited online through the website Prolific and will be tested using the Ibex experimental platform. Participants will be American or Canadian monolingual speakers of English between the ages of 18-35. They will all be right-handed. They will receive 0.85 pounds Sterling for their participation. Participants who answer less than 75% of filler comprehension questions correctly will be excluded from the analysis. 
The reading time data will be log-transformed. Individual observations will be removed from the analysis if they are more than 3 standard deviations away from the condition mean.

q13.value: 220 participants will read 9 critical stories and 10 filler stories each.

q14.value: The number was determined via a power analysis through simulation using pre-existing data as a starting point, following the guidelines provided by Green & Macleod(20016) and using the corresponding R package SimR. For the power analysis, we set the minimum Cohen's d effect size of interest at 0.2 and calculated how many participants we would need to achieve 80% power based on this effect size for every one of the comparisons described in the hypotheses section. We settled on 220 participants because with this number all comparisons should reach at least 80% power.

question.value: See the attached pdf file for all critical items in every condition and corresponding comprehension questions.

We will measure reading times of our target utterances. The reading times will be log-transformed prior to analysis, so that log(RTs) will be the dependent variable used.
We will also measure the question-answering behavior of the questions following both the critical items and the filler items. The accuracy of responses to the filler items will be used as an exclusion criterion, whereas answers to the question in the critical conditions will be used to determine comprehension of either a literal or ironic intent of the critical sentences.

The data will be analyzed fitting a mixed-effects logistic regression model for the accuracy data and a mixed-effects linear regression model for the reading times data. Both models will include a 'maximal' random-effects structure (Barr et al.,2013) with random intercepts and slopes by items and by participants. If any of the models fails to converge, the random effects structure will be reduced in the following order:
1. Remove random correlation of random effects by subjects and then by items
2.Remove random intercepts by subjects and then by items

The model for the reading times will be fitted twice with two different contrast coding schemes. The first one will use a sum-contrast coding scheme (testing main effects and interactions) and the second one a slider-contrast coding scheme (testing simple effects, or differences between individual conditions).

q20.value: The reading times will be log-transformed, following the procedure used for analyzing the data of the previous identical experiment, in order to help normalize the residuals of the regression model.

q21.value: Statistical inference will follow the model of null-hypothesis significance testing, with an alpha level set at 0.05: P-values below this threshold will be taken as evidence against the null-hypothesis. Additionally, we will consider statistical significance in relation to the size of specific effects: We expect the predicted effects to have a cohen's d value of at least 0.2.

q22.value:
Data will be excluded in 3 ways:

1. Participants who answer less than 75% of the filler comprehension questions accurately will be excluded from the analysis.
2. log-transformed reading times more than 3 standard deviations away from the condition mean will be excluded. 
3. If a participant answered a critical comprehension question incorrectly (i.e. understood the sentence literally in the insincere condtions or ironically in the sincere conditions), the reading times from this trial will be excluded from the analysis.

q1.value: Investigating Effects of Musical Stimuli on Mood and Characteristics Associated with the Enjoyment of Sad Music

q3.value: Although people oftentimes avoid negative emotions, they at times enjoy sadness that is portrayed through music, films, or other arts. This creates a kind of paradox situation. I am interested in looking at this paradox and different aspects that may play a role in the enjoyment of sad music, such as empathy, affect intensity, and aesthetic appreciation. I will also be looking at the effects of different types of music (happy and sad) on mood and the liking of that music. I want to examine the differences between the two groups to determine if the type of music that we listen to has an effect on our mood afterward.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: I predict that individuals in the happy music condition will indicate having a happier mood after treatment, and individuals in the sad music condition will indicate a sadder mood after treatment. 
Hypothesis 2: There is a positive correlation between empathy and the liking of sad music.
Hypothesis 3: There is a positive correlation between affect intensity and the liking of sad music.
Hypothesis 4: There is a positive correlation between aesthetic appreciation and the liking of sad music.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: I will be collecting observational data from participants in the form of a survey before random assignment occurs. I will then be performing a between-subjects experiment with 1 factor (music) and 2 levels (happy, sad).

q9.value: I will use simple randomization. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups (happy or sad). To accomplish the process of random assignment, I will have slips of paper with ordered letters for the letter of the labeled treatment rooms that there are in the testing lab. Half of the letters will be classified as the sad condition room, and the other half will be classified as the happy condition room. The letters  will be mixed into a basket and participants will draw a random letter to randomly determine what condition that they will be assigned.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: During data collection, surveys were placed into a folder by participants and have not been observed or analyzed by anyone.

question.value:
Participants in my study will consist of undergraduate students from Olivet Nazarene
University. Participants will be recruited from various psychology courses, and the sign-up sheet will be handed out by the professors that I have had in past classes. Students will be given the opportunity to voluntarily partake in the study and will be offered extra credit in their course for their participation. Those who are interested in participating in the study will be provided with a sign-up sheet that contains dates and times available to volunteer for the experiment. Those interested will sign-up for a time that works best for them by writing their name and email in the time slot so that I can contact them if needed prior to the study. I will give out the sign-up sheet a week before data collection begins, and will contact the professors offering extra credit for partaking in it as soon as data collection is finished.

q13.value: The target sample size for the experiment is 40 participants. I plan to recruit 48 participants, assuming that not everyone will show up.

q14.value: Time, money, and a limited participant pool lead to the target size of 40 individuals.

q15.value: I will have two days to collect data and will have 8 time slots with 6 participant spots for each, therefore, I will not exceed 48 participants.

question.value: I plan to manipulate the type of music a participant listens to by having a sad music condition and a happy music condition in order to measure their mood after manipulation.

For the experimental part of my study, the single outcome variable will be "mood" after listening to three musical excerpts (either happy or sad). Mood will be measured using the Brief Mood Introspection Scale, which instructs participants to circle how well each of the sixteen adjectives or phrases listed describes their current mood (e.g happy, sad, calm, gloomy), ranging from 1 (definitely do not feel) to 4 (definitely feel) (Gaschke & Mayor, 2013). 
In the correlational part of my study, the variables that I will be measuring are empathy, affect intensity, aesthetic appreciation, and the liking of sad music. Affect Intensity will be measured using the Affect Intensity Measure which consists of twenty items (e.g. I get really happy or really unhappy; I get upset easily). The AIM uses a six-point scale of measurement ranging from 1 (“never”) to 6 (“always”) (Larsen, 1984). Empathy will be measured using the Interpersonal Reactivity Index, which contains twenty-eight items (e.g. After seeing a play or movie, I have felt as though I were one of the characters; I am often quite touched by things that I see happen). The IRI uses a five-point scale ranging from 1 (“does not describe me well”) to 5 (“describes me very well”) (Davis, 1980). Aesthetic appreciation will be measured using the Aesthetic Appreciation subsection of the HEXACO scale (Ashton & Lee, 2009), which consists of four items that are measured on a five-point scale from “strongly disagree” to “strongly agree. To measure the liking of sad music, the scale that will be used is a ” 5-point Likert scale with endpoints that range from 1 (Strongly Disliked) to 5 (Strongly Liked) and a five-point Likert scale measuring how much participants like both happy and sad music. I generated these scales in order to correlate the liking of sad music and empathy, affect intensity, and aesthetic appreciation.

I will be analyzing Hypothesis 1 using a one-way between subject’s ANOVA. 
I will be analyzing Hypothesis 2 using Pearson's r statistical analysis. 
I will be analyzing Hypothesis 3 using Pearson's r statistical analysis. 
I will be analyzing Hypothesis 4 using Pearson's r statistical analysis.

q20.value: I will not be transforming any of the data. Reverse coded items will be re-coded using the scale provided by the author of the scale.

q21.value:
I will use p<.05 as the standard for determining statistical significance. 
I will be using one-tailed tests for Hyotheses 2, 3, and 4. 
I will only be comparing two conditions (happy, sad).

q22.value: Participants will be excluded if they fail to complete any of the measures. Due to having such a small sample size, analyses will be run both with and without outliers.

q23.value: If a participant fails to complete any of the measures, he or she will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: I will look for relationships between demographic variables (gender, age, class) and the liking of certain types of music (happy, sad), empathy scores, affect intensity scores, and aesthetic appreciation scores.

q25.value:
Ashton, M. C., & Lee, K. (2009). The HEXACO-60: A short measure of the major dimensions
of personality. Journal of Personality Assessment, 91, 340-345.
Davis, m. h. (1980). A multidimensional approach to individual differences in empathy. JSAS
Catalog of Selected Documents in Psychology, 10, 85
Gaschke, Y. N. & Mayer, J. D. (2013) . Brief Mood Introspection Scale (BMIS) . Measurement
Instrument Database for the Social Science. Retrieved from www.midss.ie
Larsen, R. J., & Diener, E. (1987). Affect intensity as an individual difference characteristic: A
review. Journal of Research in Personality, 21(1), 1–39. https://doi.org/10.
1016/00926566(87)90023-

attributes.title: A Scoping Review of Primary Care Models and Performance

summary.value:
Primary care (PC) is the cornerstone for health services in most countries around the world. Countries that have a strong PC system achieve better health at individual and community levels. Previous studies identified numerous models of PC. PC takes different forms in different countries, and differences in PC arrangements exist even within the same countries. A significant aspect of evaluating these different models of PC is through performance indicators. Performance measurement in PC is challenging because of the complexity in these sittings (tasks, policies, professionals, and models itself).   
This review aims to identify the different models of PC, identify core indicators of PC performance, and examine the previous studies that evaluated and compared PC models. A scoping review design seems to be the best fit for this purpose. This protocol presents a detailed step by step description of the proposed methods including research questions, search strategy, eligibility criteria for study selection (inclusion and exclusion criteria), data extraction and synthesis. This protocol will be registered with the Open Science Framework initiative before starting this review.

attributes.title: A Step Towards the Culture of Scientific Communication
attributes.description: Description of the functional interactive model for indicating the status of the scientific community in real time

summary.value:
The most valuable resource of science is time.
Therefore, the main question is, will each scientist on the planet have 3 minutes to participate in the experiment?
If yes, then the scientific community is the most influential global collective entity today, capable of unprecedented consolidation of efforts.
The presented project is at the startup stage. At this stage, the main organizational issues are solved: the base, sources of financing and development participants are determined.
The second stage, the development stage, involves the technical embodiment of the GBI model. At the same time, the next stage is being prepared - experimental testing, for which several parties involved (various institutions) are required.
But the implementation of the project (the fourth stage) is not the end. It implies the creation of an open, constantly updated database, the use of which is not limited to the narrow special tasks of studying the culture of scientific communication.

attributes.title: Evaluation of a Parent Training ProgrammeProgram for Families of Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder in China: Protocol for a Mixed-Methods Quasi-Experimental Study

q1.value: Evaluation of a Parent Training ProgrammeProgram for Families of Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder in China: A Mixed-Methods Quasi-Experimental Study

q2.value: Zuyi Fang, Jane Barlow, Jamie Lachman

q3.value: This project involves a quasi-experiement of a parent training program for families of children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) aged 3 to 6 years in mainland China. The program has been delivered by the NGO of Beijing Stars and Rain Education Institute for Autism (SREIA) for decades. The study will be conducted in routine settings to evaluate the effectiveness of the SREIA program.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: The SREIA parent training program will significantly reduce parent-reported child behavior problems, as measured by the Externalizing scale of the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) for Ages 1.5-5, in comparison to a waitlist control group.

Hypothesis 2: The SREIA parent training program will have a significant effect on the secondary outcomes, including reducing reducing ASD symptoms and improving parental and familial outcomes including parental knowledge of ASD and ABA techniques, parenting styles, parental mental health (including stress, anxiety and depression), and family functioning.

Hypothesis 3: Higher levels of participant involvement will be associated with greater improvements in the outcomes.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: Due to the nature of parent training and the use of a waitlist control group, it will not be possible to blind participants or facilitators. However, research staff who collect the data will be blinded for the baseline and immediate post-intervention assessment. Data collectors will not be involved in the delivery process and will be trained on the topic of risk of bias. Parents will also be asked to keep their allocation condition private from outcome data collectors. Process evaluation data will be collected by a separate group of research staff. Given that all families will ultimately receive the training, blinding will not be possible at the 6-months follow-up assessment. Blinding will be protected and monitored, while the violation of blinding will be detected and incorporated into the interpretation of results.

question.value: A pragmatic multi-wave quasi-experimental trial design will be conducted. Mixed methods will be used with a nested design, in which the qualitative approach will be embedded within the quantitative method to better understand the quantitative data obtained (Creswell, 2011). The study will be conducted within the context of routine services and will involve two consecutive deliveries of the SREIA program. One hundred families of children with ASD age three to six will be recruited and allocated to the two waves of delivery with a 1:1 ratio. Participants will be self-selected into either version. The 50 families who choose to participate in the first wave will be the treatment group, and the 50 families in the second wave will service as the waitlist control group.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Recruitment of participants has not started. No data has been collected.

question.value:
1. Inclusion and exclusion criteria

1.1 Families
The recruitment criteria will follow the existing strategies used by the NGO that provides the SREIA program. The age range of children will be three to six years old, and all participating children will need to meet the diagnostic criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder according to DSM-V; otherwise, an official letter of ASD diagnosis will need to be provided. Families will be excluded if the child has been diagnosed with Cerebral Palsy. Each family will have one parent (or primary caregiver) and one child participating in the program. Participating primary caregivers will be those who 1) undertake the responsibility for the daily care of the child for at least five days a week and 2) provide informed consent to participate in the research. There will be no additional exclusion criteria. Despite the fact that the service will be provided in Beijing, recruitment will not be restricted to families in Beijing, but open to families from every administrative division in China.

1.2 Facilitators
Program facilitators will be employees of the NGO in Beijing. Only facilitators who have provided informed consent will participate in the assessment of the program implementation.

1.3 NGO managers
The NGO managers consist of the founder, CEO, and program development officers of the NGO. Five NGO managers will be invited to take part in an interview, but only those who agree and provide informed consent, will take part. 

2 Study setting
The program will be delivered in the SREIA venues in the Chaoyang District of Beijing. Both sites are physically close to each other and located at the east border of the inner city of Beijing and away from the city center, but with easy access to public transportation.

3. Recruitment of families
Enrolment will be on a first-come, first-served basis. Potential participants will first be recruited from an existing waiting list for the SREIA program. When necessary, more participants will be recruited online, by word of mouth, or by referrals from other service agencies and hospitals. It will be made explicit to potential participants that these two rounds of parent training are delivered for the purpose of evaluation. Families will decide which round of delivery and which version to attend according to their own preference and availability. Staff will provide information sheets and introduce the study to families who intend to attend the parent training before they are officially enrolled. Families will be able to contact the research team regarding project details or any concerns, before they give written consent. Participation in the study will be voluntary. Parents who are not willing to participate in the study will be advised to attend the training after the evaluation. On rare occasions, there may be parents who insist in attending the training during the evaluation but prefer not to provide data; those parents will be enrolled in the program but will not be required to participate in the research. 

4. Incentives
Family participants will be offered discounts on program fees. Facilitators and NGO manager will not be given any reimbursement but will receive a formal Thank You letter for participation in the research.

q13.value: The study will be conducted in routine service settings and involve two waves of routine delivery of the SREIA program. Fifty families will be enrolled in each wave of delivery.

q14.value:
A power calculation was conducted using the PWR package in R Studio (Cohen, 2013). The review conducted by Fang et al. (2020, forthcoming) showed that parent training programs for families of children with ASD aged one to eleven in China had an effect size of g = -1.37 (95% CI [-2.03, -0.71]) on child emotional and behavioral problems, whereas Postorino et al. (2017) found a smaller effect size SMD=-0.59 (95% CI, [-0.88, -0.30]) in reducing disruptive behaviors in children with ASD aged between two to fourteen years. The power calculation was based on Postorino et al. (2017) in order to increase the statistical power. The sample size calculation shows that with a significance level of 0.05 and statistical power of 0.8 in a two-sample, two-tailed t-test, the sample size necessary to detect any significant effect is 94 (47 in each arm). 

Since the study will be conducted in a routine setting by an NGO with limited capacity, it will involve two rounds of delivery with a maximum sample size of 100 (50 in the first round serving as the treatment group and 50 in the second round as the waitlist control). This will enable a minimal detectable effect size of g = -0.56 on the primary outcome measure. Based previous delivery of the program to date, parents are typically highly committed, contributing to a low program attrition rate of 2% in the past three years. Allowing for this level of attrition, the proposed sample size can still give a detectable change in the region of approximately g = 0.57. If the attrition is increased to 5%, the sample will only be able to detect a slightly larger effect size of g = 0.58. The two rounds of delivery will also in total comprise of 60 families in Version A and 40 in Version B, which can potentially detect a difference of g = 0.57 in the two versions.

question.value:
Intervention: The SREIA Parent Training Program

The SREIA parent training program was developed by SREIA during the 1990s and has been evolving over the past two decades. The program is grounded in Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) [28,29]. It aims to promote positive behaviors and child development by improving parental attitudes and parenting styles. The program targets parent-child dyads from families of children with ASD aged between three and six years. It is delivered five days a week, with three hours in the morning and two hours in the afternoon, for 11 weeks. Fourteen two-hour lectures on weekly themes (such as knowledge of ASD, parent-child interaction, and behavior management techniques) are offered throughout the 11 weeks and attended by all participating parents. Weekly topics include 1) knowledge of ASD, 2) Applied Behavioral Analysis, 3) child behavior problems, 4) reinforcement, 5) parent-child communication, 6) differential reinforcement and prompts, 7) fading and shaping, 8) chaining, and 9) generation and maintenance. For the remaining time, additional training in ABA principles and practice are tailored for the different functioning groups. Although a program framework specifies the themes covered each week, there is an inbuilt flexibility in terms of program content and the delivery mode for each session within the week. For example, depending on child ability and parental acquisition of skills, facilitators may decide whether and when to strengthen the basic skills, or to move on to more advanced skills. The program is delivered in person through a combination of individual counselling and group sessions, as well as a mixture of didactic and interactive delivery modes. Some sessions are only for parents, while others are participated in by both parent and child. Childcare is provided during by NGO staff parent group sessions. A wide range of session types and delivery methods are used in the training, such facilitator modeling, parent practicing, and in-vivo feedback.


Treatment group will receive the intervention during the 1st wave of delivery.

1. Outcome measurements:

Data will be collected  at baseline (T0), immediately post-intervention (T1), and 6-month post-interventio (T2, conditional to funding). For questionnaires that do not have a Chinese version, the translation followed the WHO guideline of Process of Translation and Adaptation of Instruments (World Health Organization, 2020).

1.1. Primary outcome
Child behavioral problems will be assessed using the Externalizing scale of the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) for Ages 1.5-5 (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001). The Externalizing scale measures child attention problems and aggressive behaviors using 24 items rated by parents with a 3-point -type scale. The study will use the CBCL 1.5-5 for all families whose children will be between three to six years old, because 1) it is anticipated that the majority of children will be under six, 2) CBCL 1.5-5 has been shown good internal consistency among children with ASD aged six to seven (Basten et al., 2014), and 3) many items in the Externalizing scale of CBCL 6-18 (such as drink alcohol, lie/cheat, use tobacco or drugs, and truant) are not applicable for children with ASD aged six. Lower scores suggest fewer behavioral problems. Research has shown sufficient test-retest reliability, internal consistency, convergent validity, and cross-cultural validity of CBCL 2-3 and CBCL 4-18 in China (Leung et al., 2006; Liu, Wu, & Yao, 2003; Su, Li, Wan, Yang, & Luo, 1996), but the evidence regarding the validity and reliability of this new version of CBCL 1.5-5 is currently limited. However, the CBCL 1.5-5 has shown good factorial validity among Chinese girls adopted into North American families (Tan, Dedrick, & Marfo, 2007); it has also demonstrated good internal validity with children with ASD (Pandolfi, Magyar, & Dill, 2009).

1.2 Secondary outcomes
ASD symptoms will be assessed using the Chinese version of the Autism Treatment Evaluation Checklist (ATEC) (Rimland & Edelson, 1999), which comprise four subscales to measure child speech/language/communication, sociability, sensory/cognitive awareness, and health/physical/behavior. The scale has 77 items that are scored by parents. The health/physical/behavior subscale is rated using a 0 (not a problem)-to-3 (serious problem) point scale, whereas the other three subscales are rated using a 0 (not true)-to-2 (very true) point scale. Higher scores represent more ASD symptoms. The ATEC has shown sufficient internal consistency and test-retest reliability internationally and in China (Geier, Kern, & Geier, 2013; Lu, Yang, Shu, & Su, 2004; Magiati, Moss, Yates, Charman, & Howlin, 2011), as well as cross-contextual validity (Jarusiewicz, 2002). 

Parenting style will be measured using the Over-Reactivity subscale (5 items) of the Arnold-O’Leary Parenting Scale (PS) (Arnold, O’Leary, Wolff, & Acker, 1993), and the Supporting Positive Behavior subscale (7 items) of the Parenting Young Children Scale (PARYC) (McEachern et al., 2012). The PS assesses dysfunctional discipline practices reported by parents using a 7-point Likert-type scale. Higher scores indicate more dysfunctional parenting practices. Sufficient internal consistency and convergent and divergent validity has been demonstrated for the use of PS in Hong Kong (C. Leung, Sanders, Leung, Mak, & Lau, 2003; Zhu, 2018). The PARYC Supporting Positive Behavior subscale is rated by parents from 1 to 7 regarding the frequency with which they engaged in such parenting strategies during the last month. Higher scores represent more positive and proactive parenting practices. The PARYC has exhibited sufficient construct and convergent validity and internal consistency in other studies (McEachern et al., 2012), but there is currently limited evidence regarding validity and reliability in the Chinese population.

Parental mental health will be assessed using the Chinese version of the Depression Anxiety Stress Scale-21 items (DASS-21) (Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995), which consists of three self-report subscales (depression, anxiety, and stress) with each having 7 items that are rated from 0 (not apply to me) to 3 (apply to me very much or most of the time). Higher scores indicate a worse emotional state. The scale has been shown to have good internal consistency, test-retest reliability, and cross-cultural validity in China (Chan et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2016). 

Family function will be assessed using the Chinese version of the Family APGAR scale (Smilkstein, Ashworth, & Montano, 1982), which consists of 5 items that are rated from 0 (never) to 2 (often) to examine the five functional components of adaptability, partnership, growth, affection, and resolve. Higher scores indicate that parents are more satisfied with their relationships with other family members. The Chinese version of this scale has demonstrated good internal consistency and test-retest reliability in Chinese population (Lin et al., 2008; Nan et al., 2014; Zheng, Shi, & Mao, 1996).

Parental knowledge will be measured using of the scores of several quizzes designed for use with the SREIA program to assess parental understanding and utilization of ABA techniques taught during the sessions. The quizzes on ABA principles and techniques will be administered at all time points in order to compare the change over time. 

2 Process evaluation outcomes
The implementation of the program will be explored regarding four criteria: program acceptability, participant involvement, program delivery, and sustainability.

Program Acceptability will be assessed at post-intervention only using a questionnaire based on the Incredible Years® Autism Program End-of-Course Satisfaction Questionnaire (Incredible Years, n.d.) tailored to the SREIA program and Chinese context. The questionnaire covers a range of topics including overall impression; teaching format; information and techniques; facilitators; and parent groups. It consists of 30 items rated with a 3-point Likert-type scale. High scores represent higher levels of satisfaction.

The level of participant involvement will be captured by calculating rates of attendance, engagement, and program dropout. The attendance rate will be assessed with an attendance sheet, which will be reported by facilitators and collected twice a day (morning and afternoon); engagement rate will be based on the percentage of families who complete assigned homework and tasks during the practice sessions, using an attendance and engagement registry; program dropout rate will be calculated based on families who miss at least ten days. Participant involvement, as well as program acceptability, will also be assessed using qualitative interviews with parents, focus groups with facilitators and NGO managers, and facilitator supervision sessions. 

Program Delivery will be measured through two dimensions—fidelity and quality of delivery. Implementation fidelity will be measured using facilitator checklists. Facilitators will report whether they deliver the core components prescribed in the manual after each session. The fidelity score will comprise the ratio of delivered components to prescribed components. Dosage will be calculated using hours of delivery. Quality of delivery will be assessed by research staff observing parent group sessions and filling out a quality of delivery survey. The in-depth interviews with NGO managers, focus group discussion with facilitators and supervision notes will also investigate the delivery of the program.

Program Sustainability will be explored during the qualitative interviews with NGO managers, which will be guided by the RE-AIM (reach, effectiveness, adopt, implementation, and maintenance) framework (Glasgow, Vogt, & Boles, 1999). The interviews will focus on community- and policy-level factors that may affect program sustainability and scale-up.
Not applicable

Quantitative data analyses will be conducted using R Studio (R Core Team, 2013). Data analysis will follow the principles of intent-to-treat, which involves assessing all participants as originally allocated, regardless of program dropouts or the dose of treatment they received. Missing data and its association with other variables will be assessed using logistic regression. Where appropriate, full-information maximum likelihood (FIML) will be used to compensate for missing data (Schafer & Graham, 2002).

A table showing the demographic characteristics of participants will be compiled (M±SD for continuous variables and percentages for categorical variables). The analysis will comprise a between-group comparison for the treatment and the waitlist control groups after the first wave of delivery (T1) to investigate the treatment effects.

To reduce selection bias and improve baseline balance for the between-group comparison, the treatment effects of the intervention will be estimated using a difference-in-differences (DiD) design with inverse propensity score weights (Stuart et al., 2014). The weighting of propensity scores will help to keep all available data in the analysis, in order to improve the statistical power. Propensity scores will be calculated using logistic regression based on key variables that may affect intervention effects, including baseline outcome scores (i.e., child behavior problems, ASD severity, parenting styles, parental mental health, parental knowledge, and family function) and demographic characteristics (i.e., parental education levels and economic status), as well as other variables that demonstrate baseline imbalance. With the propensity scores, the treatment and control groups will be weighted to be balanced on the key variables; weighted regression models will then be fitted for the DiD analyses, which further adjust for unobserved variables and secular time trends. Clustering effects within each treatment condition and child levels of functioning group will also be accounted for. Exploratory statistical analyses will be conducted to understand the differences in treatment effects between the two different versions of delivery. Attrition weights for program dropouts (if any) will be combined. Propensity score weights will be estimated using the TWANG (Toolkit for Weighting and Analysis of Nonequivalent Groups) package in R (Ridgeway, McCaffrey, Morral, Burgette, & Griffin, 2014). 

Means and standard deviations will be calculated for participant satisfaction, attendance rate, engagement rate, program dropout rate, and quality of delivery. Implementation fidelity will be reported using a ratio of delivered components to prescribed components. Regression models will be created to explore potential predictors of participant involvement, as well as investigate possible associations between implementation aspect (i.e., particularly participant involvement and program satisfaction but may also include any salient features identified from the qualitative data analysis) and treatment effects. Participant characteristics will be controlled for in the regression analyses.

q20.value: There will be no transformation of the data.

q21.value: The means, standard deviations, p-value, and confidence intervals (95%) will be reported.  Hedges' g will be reported with effect sizes of 0.2-0.49 as small, 0.5-0.79 as moderate, and 0.8 as large .

q22.value: Efforts will be made to reduce incomplete data. Outliers will be included.

q23.value: Where appropriate, full-information maximum likelihood (FIML) will be used to compensate for missing data (Schafer & Graham, 2002).

registration_responses.q1: Evaluation of a Parent Training ProgrammeProgram for Families of Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder in China: A Mixed-Methods Quasi-Experimental Study
registration_responses.q2: Zuyi Fang, Jane Barlow, Jamie Lachman
registration_responses.q3: This project involves a quasi-experiement of a parent training program for families of children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) aged 3 to 6 years in mainland China. The program has been delivered by the NGO of Beijing Stars and Rain Education Institute for Autism (SREIA) for decades. The study will be conducted in routine settings to evaluate the effectiveness of the SREIA program.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1: The SREIA parent training program will significantly reduce parent-reported child behavior problems, as measured by the Externalizing scale of the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) for Ages 1.5-5, in comparison to a waitlist control group.

Hypothesis 2: The SREIA parent training program will have a significant effect on the secondary outcomes, including reducing reducing ASD symptoms and improving parental and familial outcomes including parental knowledge of ASD and ABA techniques, parenting styles, parental mental health (including stress, anxiety and depression), and family functioning.

Hypothesis 3: Higher levels of participant involvement will be associated with greater improvements in the outcomes.
q6: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
registration_responses.q7: Due to the nature of parent training and the use of a waitlist control group, it will not be possible to blind participants or facilitators. However, research staff who collect the data will be blinded for the baseline and immediate post-intervention assessment. Data collectors will not be involved in the delivery process and will be trained on the topic of risk of bias. Parents will also be asked to keep their allocation condition private from outcome data collectors. Process evaluation data will be collected by a separate group of research staff. Given that all families will ultimately receive the training, blinding will not be possible at the 6-months follow-up assessment. Blinding will be protected and monitored, while the violation of blinding will be detected and incorporated into the interpretation of results.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: Recruitment of participants has not started. No data has been collected.
registration_responses.q13: The study will be conducted in routine service settings and involve two waves of routine delivery of the SREIA program. Fifty families will be enrolled in each wave of delivery.
registration_responses.q14:
A power calculation was conducted using the PWR package in R Studio (Cohen, 2013). The review conducted by Fang et al. (2020, forthcoming) showed that parent training programs for families of children with ASD aged one to eleven in China had an effect size of g = -1.37 (95% CI [-2.03, -0.71]) on child emotional and behavioral problems, whereas Postorino et al. (2017) found a smaller effect size SMD=-0.59 (95% CI, [-0.88, -0.30]) in reducing disruptive behaviors in children with ASD aged between two to fourteen years. The power calculation was based on Postorino et al. (2017) in order to increase the statistical power. The sample size calculation shows that with a significance level of 0.05 and statistical power of 0.8 in a two-sample, two-tailed t-test, the sample size necessary to detect any significant effect is 94 (47 in each arm). 

Since the study will be conducted in a routine setting by an NGO with limited capacity, it will involve two rounds of delivery with a maximum sample size of 100 (50 in the first round serving as the treatment group and 50 in the second round as the waitlist control). This will enable a minimal detectable effect size of g = -0.56 on the primary outcome measure. Based previous delivery of the program to date, parents are typically highly committed, contributing to a low program attrition rate of 2% in the past three years. Allowing for this level of attrition, the proposed sample size can still give a detectable change in the region of approximately g = 0.57. If the attrition is increased to 5%, the sample will only be able to detect a slightly larger effect size of g = 0.58. The two rounds of delivery will also in total comprise of 60 families in Version A and 40 in Version B, which can potentially detect a difference of g = 0.57 in the two versions.
registration_responses.q20: There will be no transformation of the data.
registration_responses.q21: The means, standard deviations, p-value, and confidence intervals (95%) will be reported.  Hedges' g will be reported with effect sizes of 0.2-0.49 as small, 0.5-0.79 as moderate, and 0.8 as large .
registration_responses.q22: Efforts will be made to reduce incomplete data. Outliers will be included.
registration_responses.q23: Where appropriate, full-information maximum likelihood (FIML) will be used to compensate for missing data (Schafer & Graham, 2002).

registration_responses.q8.question: A pragmatic multi-wave quasi-experimental trial design will be conducted. Mixed methods will be used with a nested design, in which the qualitative approach will be embedded within the quantitative method to better understand the quantitative data obtained (Creswell, 2011). The study will be conducted within the context of routine services and will involve two consecutive deliveries of the SREIA program. One hundred families of children with ASD age three to six will be recruited and allocated to the two waves of delivery with a 1:1 ratio. Participants will be self-selected into either version. The 50 families who choose to participate in the first wave will be the treatment group, and the 50 families in the second wave will service as the waitlist control group.
registration_responses.q12.question:
1. Inclusion and exclusion criteria

1.1 Families
The recruitment criteria will follow the existing strategies used by the NGO that provides the SREIA program. The age range of children will be three to six years old, and all participating children will need to meet the diagnostic criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder according to DSM-V; otherwise, an official letter of ASD diagnosis will need to be provided. Families will be excluded if the child has been diagnosed with Cerebral Palsy. Each family will have one parent (or primary caregiver) and one child participating in the program. Participating primary caregivers will be those who 1) undertake the responsibility for the daily care of the child for at least five days a week and 2) provide informed consent to participate in the research. There will be no additional exclusion criteria. Despite the fact that the service will be provided in Beijing, recruitment will not be restricted to families in Beijing, but open to families from every administrative division in China.

1.2 Facilitators
Program facilitators will be employees of the NGO in Beijing. Only facilitators who have provided informed consent will participate in the assessment of the program implementation.

1.3 NGO managers
The NGO managers consist of the founder, CEO, and program development officers of the NGO. Five NGO managers will be invited to take part in an interview, but only those who agree and provide informed consent, will take part. 

2 Study setting
The program will be delivered in the SREIA venues in the Chaoyang District of Beijing. Both sites are physically close to each other and located at the east border of the inner city of Beijing and away from the city center, but with easy access to public transportation.

3. Recruitment of families
Enrolment will be on a first-come, first-served basis. Potential participants will first be recruited from an existing waiting list for the SREIA program. When necessary, more participants will be recruited online, by word of mouth, or by referrals from other service agencies and hospitals. It will be made explicit to potential participants that these two rounds of parent training are delivered for the purpose of evaluation. Families will decide which round of delivery and which version to attend according to their own preference and availability. Staff will provide information sheets and introduce the study to families who intend to attend the parent training before they are officially enrolled. Families will be able to contact the research team regarding project details or any concerns, before they give written consent. Participation in the study will be voluntary. Parents who are not willing to participate in the study will be advised to attend the training after the evaluation. On rare occasions, there may be parents who insist in attending the training during the evaluation but prefer not to provide data; those parents will be enrolled in the program but will not be required to participate in the research. 

4. Incentives
Family participants will be offered discounts on program fees. Facilitators and NGO manager will not be given any reimbursement but will receive a formal Thank You letter for participation in the research.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Intervention: The SREIA Parent Training Program

The SREIA parent training program was developed by SREIA during the 1990s and has been evolving over the past two decades. The program is grounded in Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) [28,29]. It aims to promote positive behaviors and child development by improving parental attitudes and parenting styles. The program targets parent-child dyads from families of children with ASD aged between three and six years. It is delivered five days a week, with three hours in the morning and two hours in the afternoon, for 11 weeks. Fourteen two-hour lectures on weekly themes (such as knowledge of ASD, parent-child interaction, and behavior management techniques) are offered throughout the 11 weeks and attended by all participating parents. Weekly topics include 1) knowledge of ASD, 2) Applied Behavioral Analysis, 3) child behavior problems, 4) reinforcement, 5) parent-child communication, 6) differential reinforcement and prompts, 7) fading and shaping, 8) chaining, and 9) generation and maintenance. For the remaining time, additional training in ABA principles and practice are tailored for the different functioning groups. Although a program framework specifies the themes covered each week, there is an inbuilt flexibility in terms of program content and the delivery mode for each session within the week. For example, depending on child ability and parental acquisition of skills, facilitators may decide whether and when to strengthen the basic skills, or to move on to more advanced skills. The program is delivered in person through a combination of individual counselling and group sessions, as well as a mixture of didactic and interactive delivery modes. Some sessions are only for parents, while others are participated in by both parent and child. Childcare is provided during by NGO staff parent group sessions. A wide range of session types and delivery methods are used in the training, such facilitator modeling, parent practicing, and in-vivo feedback.


Treatment group will receive the intervention during the 1st wave of delivery.
registration_responses.q17.question:
1. Outcome measurements:

Data will be collected  at baseline (T0), immediately post-intervention (T1), and 6-month post-interventio (T2, conditional to funding). For questionnaires that do not have a Chinese version, the translation followed the WHO guideline of Process of Translation and Adaptation of Instruments (World Health Organization, 2020).

1.1. Primary outcome
Child behavioral problems will be assessed using the Externalizing scale of the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) for Ages 1.5-5 (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001). The Externalizing scale measures child attention problems and aggressive behaviors using 24 items rated by parents with a 3-point -type scale. The study will use the CBCL 1.5-5 for all families whose children will be between three to six years old, because 1) it is anticipated that the majority of children will be under six, 2) CBCL 1.5-5 has been shown good internal consistency among children with ASD aged six to seven (Basten et al., 2014), and 3) many items in the Externalizing scale of CBCL 6-18 (such as drink alcohol, lie/cheat, use tobacco or drugs, and truant) are not applicable for children with ASD aged six. Lower scores suggest fewer behavioral problems. Research has shown sufficient test-retest reliability, internal consistency, convergent validity, and cross-cultural validity of CBCL 2-3 and CBCL 4-18 in China (Leung et al., 2006; Liu, Wu, & Yao, 2003; Su, Li, Wan, Yang, & Luo, 1996), but the evidence regarding the validity and reliability of this new version of CBCL 1.5-5 is currently limited. However, the CBCL 1.5-5 has shown good factorial validity among Chinese girls adopted into North American families (Tan, Dedrick, & Marfo, 2007); it has also demonstrated good internal validity with children with ASD (Pandolfi, Magyar, & Dill, 2009).

1.2 Secondary outcomes
ASD symptoms will be assessed using the Chinese version of the Autism Treatment Evaluation Checklist (ATEC) (Rimland & Edelson, 1999), which comprise four subscales to measure child speech/language/communication, sociability, sensory/cognitive awareness, and health/physical/behavior. The scale has 77 items that are scored by parents. The health/physical/behavior subscale is rated using a 0 (not a problem)-to-3 (serious problem) point scale, whereas the other three subscales are rated using a 0 (not true)-to-2 (very true) point scale. Higher scores represent more ASD symptoms. The ATEC has shown sufficient internal consistency and test-retest reliability internationally and in China (Geier, Kern, & Geier, 2013; Lu, Yang, Shu, & Su, 2004; Magiati, Moss, Yates, Charman, & Howlin, 2011), as well as cross-contextual validity (Jarusiewicz, 2002). 

Parenting style will be measured using the Over-Reactivity subscale (5 items) of the Arnold-O’Leary Parenting Scale (PS) (Arnold, O’Leary, Wolff, & Acker, 1993), and the Supporting Positive Behavior subscale (7 items) of the Parenting Young Children Scale (PARYC) (McEachern et al., 2012). The PS assesses dysfunctional discipline practices reported by parents using a 7-point Likert-type scale. Higher scores indicate more dysfunctional parenting practices. Sufficient internal consistency and convergent and divergent validity has been demonstrated for the use of PS in Hong Kong (C. Leung, Sanders, Leung, Mak, & Lau, 2003; Zhu, 2018). The PARYC Supporting Positive Behavior subscale is rated by parents from 1 to 7 regarding the frequency with which they engaged in such parenting strategies during the last month. Higher scores represent more positive and proactive parenting practices. The PARYC has exhibited sufficient construct and convergent validity and internal consistency in other studies (McEachern et al., 2012), but there is currently limited evidence regarding validity and reliability in the Chinese population.

Parental mental health will be assessed using the Chinese version of the Depression Anxiety Stress Scale-21 items (DASS-21) (Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995), which consists of three self-report subscales (depression, anxiety, and stress) with each having 7 items that are rated from 0 (not apply to me) to 3 (apply to me very much or most of the time). Higher scores indicate a worse emotional state. The scale has been shown to have good internal consistency, test-retest reliability, and cross-cultural validity in China (Chan et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2016). 

Family function will be assessed using the Chinese version of the Family APGAR scale (Smilkstein, Ashworth, & Montano, 1982), which consists of 5 items that are rated from 0 (never) to 2 (often) to examine the five functional components of adaptability, partnership, growth, affection, and resolve. Higher scores indicate that parents are more satisfied with their relationships with other family members. The Chinese version of this scale has demonstrated good internal consistency and test-retest reliability in Chinese population (Lin et al., 2008; Nan et al., 2014; Zheng, Shi, & Mao, 1996).

Parental knowledge will be measured using of the scores of several quizzes designed for use with the SREIA program to assess parental understanding and utilization of ABA techniques taught during the sessions. The quizzes on ABA principles and techniques will be administered at all time points in order to compare the change over time. 

2 Process evaluation outcomes
The implementation of the program will be explored regarding four criteria: program acceptability, participant involvement, program delivery, and sustainability.

Program Acceptability will be assessed at post-intervention only using a questionnaire based on the Incredible Years® Autism Program End-of-Course Satisfaction Questionnaire (Incredible Years, n.d.) tailored to the SREIA program and Chinese context. The questionnaire covers a range of topics including overall impression; teaching format; information and techniques; facilitators; and parent groups. It consists of 30 items rated with a 3-point Likert-type scale. High scores represent higher levels of satisfaction.

The level of participant involvement will be captured by calculating rates of attendance, engagement, and program dropout. The attendance rate will be assessed with an attendance sheet, which will be reported by facilitators and collected twice a day (morning and afternoon); engagement rate will be based on the percentage of families who complete assigned homework and tasks during the practice sessions, using an attendance and engagement registry; program dropout rate will be calculated based on families who miss at least ten days. Participant involvement, as well as program acceptability, will also be assessed using qualitative interviews with parents, focus groups with facilitators and NGO managers, and facilitator supervision sessions. 

Program Delivery will be measured through two dimensions—fidelity and quality of delivery. Implementation fidelity will be measured using facilitator checklists. Facilitators will report whether they deliver the core components prescribed in the manual after each session. The fidelity score will comprise the ratio of delivered components to prescribed components. Dosage will be calculated using hours of delivery. Quality of delivery will be assessed by research staff observing parent group sessions and filling out a quality of delivery survey. The in-depth interviews with NGO managers, focus group discussion with facilitators and supervision notes will also investigate the delivery of the program.

Program Sustainability will be explored during the qualitative interviews with NGO managers, which will be guided by the RE-AIM (reach, effectiveness, adopt, implementation, and maintenance) framework (Glasgow, Vogt, & Boles, 1999). The interviews will focus on community- and policy-level factors that may affect program sustainability and scale-up.
registration_responses.q18.question: Not applicable
registration_responses.q19.question:
Quantitative data analyses will be conducted using R Studio (R Core Team, 2013). Data analysis will follow the principles of intent-to-treat, which involves assessing all participants as originally allocated, regardless of program dropouts or the dose of treatment they received. Missing data and its association with other variables will be assessed using logistic regression. Where appropriate, full-information maximum likelihood (FIML) will be used to compensate for missing data (Schafer & Graham, 2002).

A table showing the demographic characteristics of participants will be compiled (M±SD for continuous variables and percentages for categorical variables). The analysis will comprise a between-group comparison for the treatment and the waitlist control groups after the first wave of delivery (T1) to investigate the treatment effects.

To reduce selection bias and improve baseline balance for the between-group comparison, the treatment effects of the intervention will be estimated using a difference-in-differences (DiD) design with inverse propensity score weights (Stuart et al., 2014). The weighting of propensity scores will help to keep all available data in the analysis, in order to improve the statistical power. Propensity scores will be calculated using logistic regression based on key variables that may affect intervention effects, including baseline outcome scores (i.e., child behavior problems, ASD severity, parenting styles, parental mental health, parental knowledge, and family function) and demographic characteristics (i.e., parental education levels and economic status), as well as other variables that demonstrate baseline imbalance. With the propensity scores, the treatment and control groups will be weighted to be balanced on the key variables; weighted regression models will then be fitted for the DiD analyses, which further adjust for unobserved variables and secular time trends. Clustering effects within each treatment condition and child levels of functioning group will also be accounted for. Exploratory statistical analyses will be conducted to understand the differences in treatment effects between the two different versions of delivery. Attrition weights for program dropouts (if any) will be combined. Propensity score weights will be estimated using the TWANG (Toolkit for Weighting and Analysis of Nonequivalent Groups) package in R (Ridgeway, McCaffrey, Morral, Burgette, & Griffin, 2014). 

Means and standard deviations will be calculated for participant satisfaction, attendance rate, engagement rate, program dropout rate, and quality of delivery. Implementation fidelity will be reported using a ratio of delivered components to prescribed components. Regression models will be created to explore potential predictors of participant involvement, as well as investigate possible associations between implementation aspect (i.e., particularly participant involvement and program satisfaction but may also include any salient features identified from the qualitative data analysis) and treatment effects. Participant characteristics will be controlled for in the regression analyses.

attributes.title: European Portuguese Validation of the Humor Styles Questionnaire

q1.value: European Portuguese Validation of the Humor Styles Questionnaire.

q2.value: Raquel Oliveira, Patricia Arriaga, Ana Paiva

q3.value: Humor is an important social phenomenon that has been linked to several physical and psychological health benefits. In order to fully understand its importance, we need valid and reliable measures of humor. However, at this time, no such measures, translated and validated to European Portuguese, exist. Our goal with this study is to translate, validate and evaluate the psychometric properties of the Portuguese version of the Humor Styles Questionnaire (HSQ).

q4.value:
Factorial Structure and Internal Consistency:

H1- A confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) of the translated version of the HSQ should replicate the original factor structure, with each item loading only to one category and showing loadings ≥ .50 within its corresponding dimension and present a good-excellent level of model fit (see more information about the criteria used in the Data Analysis section of this pre-registration). 

H2- The four subscales of the HSQ will show acceptable internal consistency; 

Construct Validity:

H4- In all versions of the scale (i.e. HSQ, No Humor HSQ, Humor HSQ), high internal consistency is expected to be observed (≥ .80);

H5- We expect to observe higher levels of internal consistency in the Humor-HSQ, when compared to the No-Humor-HSQ, and to the HSQ;

H6- We expect to observe higher levels of correlation between the Humor-HSQ and the HSQ, than between any of the previous two and the No-Humor-HSQ, thereby suggesting that the non-humorous elements of the scale contribute little to explain construct relevant variance.

Criterion Validity:

H7- We expect to observe positive relations between the affiliative style of humor and the (a) extraversion and (b) openness dimensions of personality. In addition, this style of humor should also correlate (c) positively with positive affect (and negatively, with negative affect),  (d) with life satisfaction and (e) subjective well-being.

H8- A positive relation is expected between the self-enhancing style of personality and the dimensions of (a) extraversion, (b) openness, (c) emotional stability and (d) agreeableness. Moreover, the self-enhancing style of humor should also correlate positively with (e) positive affect (and negatively, with negative affect), with (f) life satisfaction and (g) subjective well-being.

H9- The aggressive style of humor should be negatively correlated with the dimensions of (a) consciousness and (b) agreeableness. This style of humor should also be negatively correlated with (c) life satisfaction and (d) well-being.

H10- The self-defeating style of humor should be negatively correlated to the dimensions of (a) emotional stability and (b) consciousness. In addition, negative correlations should also be observed between this style of humor and (c) life satisfaction and (d) well-being.

Temporal Validity:

H11- We expect to observe high levels of consistency (≥ .70), for all the four dimensions of the scale, between participants repeated responses to the HSQ, considering a two-week interval.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The goal of this study is to translate the HSQ to European Portuguese and evaluate the psychometric properties in terms of its structural characteristics, construct, criterion and temporal validity.

1.	Translation:

The translation of the HSQ will follow a pre-determined protocol. First, all of the items of the HSQ (as well, as the items from the No-Humor HSQ and the Humor HSQ; see Main Data Collection section below) will be independently translated to European Portuguese by two bilingual native speakers, expert in the field of Psychology. The resulting translations will then be combined by the first author and translated back to Portuguese by two bilingual individuals (English-Portuguese and vice-versa). The resulting translated items will be checked and adjusted for by the first author, if necessary, and a pilot-evaluation study with 10 individuals will be conducted, to assure the clarity of all of the items and corresponding instructions. These individuals will be asked to rate the questionnaires in terms of its clarity and understandability. If necessary, changes resulting from the feedback of these individuals will be implemented. The result of this process will then be considered the final version of the scale.

2.	Main Data Collection:
The main data collection will be run in two stages. In the first stage, participants will be requested to fill out an online questionnaire, which will be composed of the following instruments: (a) the translated version of HSQ (Martin, Phulik-Doris, Larsen, Gray & Weir, 2003); (b) the translated version of the No-Humor HSQ (Ruch & Heintz, 2017, adapted from Martin, Phulik-Doris, Larsen, Gray & Weir, 2003); (c) the translated version of the Humor-HSQ (Ruch & Heintz, 2017, adapted from Martin, Phulik-Doris, Larsen, Gray & Weir, 2003); (d) PANAS (Watson, Clark & Tellegen, 1988; Portuguese adaptation by Galinha & Pais-Ribeiro, 2005); (e) TIPI scale (Gosling, Rentfrow & Swann, 2003; adapted to Portuguese by Nunes, Limpo, Lima & Castro, 2018); (f) Personal Well-Being Scale (Cummins, McCabe, Romeo & Gullone, 1994; adapted to Portuguese by Ribeiro & Cummins, 2008) and (g) a brief socio-demographic questionnaire. Both the No-Humor HSQ and the Humor HSQ are scales derived from the original HSQ, adapted from the work of Ruch and Heintz (2017), and are intended to provide a way to measure the effect of the context-relevant and construct-relevant (respectively) elements of the original scale’s items in explaining its variance. The PANAS, TIPI and Personal Well-Being scales will be used to evaluate the scale’s criterion validity. In addition, two attention-check items will be included at random throughout the questionnaire, to guarantee that participants are paying attention.
The socio-demographic questionnaire will include questions regarding the participant’s (a) sex; (b) age; (c) native tongue; (d) nationality; (e) education and (f) level of attention while responding to the study.
Participation in this stage of the study is expected to last between 40 and 60 minutes.

3.	Repeated Measures:
In order to evaluate the HSQ temporal validity, subjects who participated in the main data collection stage, will be asked to respond to the items of the HSQ again, two weeks after they responded for the first time.
Participation in this stage of the study is expected to last, maximum, 15 minutes.

4.	Exploratory Analysis and Measures:
This study is included in a larger project, that aims at characterizing the role of positive humor in the acceptance and attitudes towards social robots. In this context, we will also ask participants to fill the NARS (Piçarra, Giger, Pochwatko & Gonçalves, 2015). Our goal with the introduction of this measure is to analyze the existence of potential correlations between specific styles of humor and participant’s perceptions of social robots.

question.value:
A convenience sample of participants will be recruited, using online pools of participants (e.g. Prolific). To be eligible to participate in this study, participants must be young adults (18-45 years old) and speak European Portuguese as their native tongue. The data collection process is expected to last between two and three months. Data collection will occur online, using the Qualtrics platform. Participants will receive a monetary compensation for the time invested in participating in this study.

Participants will be given an inform consent prior to the start of data collection and will be provided with a very general explanation about the study’s purpose (as not to influence their responses). To avoid order effects, both the items within each scale and the different scales used, will be presented randomly to participants, with the exception of the socio-demographic questionnaire, which will be presented last of all.

Participants will be provided a debriefing statement at the end of their participation and their participation on the second stage will be asked.

q14.value: Sample size was estimated based on conventional recommendations and it includes 10 participants per item (32), and 5 participants per item for the re-test stage. These estimates are done considering an error probability of 0.05 and an expected effect size of 0.3.

q15.value: Data collection will cease when the necessary sample size is achieved.

question.value: NA
See Statistic Models section.
NA

Data will be analyzed using IBM AMOS, v. 26 and IBM SPSS, V.26.  To analyze the pattern of missing values, a Little’s MCR (Missing Completely at Random) test will be conducted, and p-values >.05, will be considered an acceptable indicator that the data is not missing at random.

To assess the overall fit and the discrepancy between the sample and fitted covariance matrices, a Χ2/df test will be conducted; with p-values above 0.05 being considered sufficient to accept the null hypotheses. CFI (Comparative Fit Index) values ≥.95 will be accepted as indicative of good comparative model fit. RMSEA (Root Mean Square Error of Approximation) will be considered acceptable if <0.08; and Standardized Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR) will be considered acceptable if <.90. In addition, the Parsimony Normed Fit Index (PNFI) will be considered acceptable if it presents values < .60.

Moreover, we will also analyze the validity (convergent and discriminant) and the reliability of the model. In this context, AVE values >.5 will be considered as indicatives of good convergent validity; and if the √ AVE is > to the values of the inter-construct correlations, we will consider the items as having good discriminant validity.

For the initial CFA, a four-factor structure will be imposed, and items will be allowed to load only in to one category. Eigenvalues and loadings <.45 will be eliminating factors for items.

To test internal consistency, we will Cronbach Alpha’s and McDonald’s Omega. Values <0.5 will be considered unacceptable; values ≥ 0.5 and <0.7 will be considered poor-questionable. McDonald’s Omega’s values ≥ 0.7 and <0.8 will be considered acceptable; values ≥ 0.8 and <0.9. Values ≥ 0.9 will be considered excellent. 

Pearson coefficient will be used to calculate the correlations between scales, using similar standards for interpretation, as the ones described in the paragraph above.

To investigate criterion validity, stepwise multiple regression will be applied. In this context, we will enter each subscale of the No-Humor HSQ first, and then each corresponding sub-scale of the original HSQ.

q20.value: Some scale items might need to be reversed according to each scale’s scoring instructions. Scale composites will also be calculated, by calculating the average score of items within a scale dimension.

q22.value: The data of participants who do not respond correctly to the two attention-check items will be dismissed. Similarly, participants whose native tongue is not European Portuguese or whose ages is not between 18-45 will also be excluded from the analysis. Some of the participants’ data can also be excluded if it is not missing at random (see Missing Data section).

q23.value: Questionnaires with 50% or more of missing answers, will be excluded from the analysis. If the missing responses percentage is inferior to that value, a missing values’ analysis will be conducted. If the values are missing at random, they will be substituted using the expectation-maximization (EM) procedure. If the pattern of missing responses is not random, those participants will be excluded from the study.

registration_responses.q1: European Portuguese Validation of the Humor Styles Questionnaire.
registration_responses.q3: Humor is an important social phenomenon that has been linked to several physical and psychological health benefits. In order to fully understand its importance, we need valid and reliable measures of humor. However, at this time, no such measures, translated and validated to European Portuguese, exist. Our goal with this study is to translate, validate and evaluate the psychometric properties of the Portuguese version of the Humor Styles Questionnaire (HSQ).
registration_responses.q4:
Factorial Structure and Internal Consistency:

H1- A confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) of the translated version of the HSQ should replicate the original factor structure, with each item loading only to one category and showing loadings ≥ .50 within its corresponding dimension and present a good-excellent level of model fit (see more information about the criteria used in the Data Analysis section of this pre-registration). 

H2- The four subscales of the HSQ will show acceptable internal consistency; 

Construct Validity:

H4- In all versions of the scale (i.e. HSQ, No Humor HSQ, Humor HSQ), high internal consistency is expected to be observed (≥ .80);

H5- We expect to observe higher levels of internal consistency in the Humor-HSQ, when compared to the No-Humor-HSQ, and to the HSQ;

H6- We expect to observe higher levels of correlation between the Humor-HSQ and the HSQ, than between any of the previous two and the No-Humor-HSQ, thereby suggesting that the non-humorous elements of the scale contribute little to explain construct relevant variance.

Criterion Validity:

H7- We expect to observe positive relations between the affiliative style of humor and the (a) extraversion and (b) openness dimensions of personality. In addition, this style of humor should also correlate (c) positively with positive affect (and negatively, with negative affect),  (d) with life satisfaction and (e) subjective well-being.

H8- A positive relation is expected between the self-enhancing style of personality and the dimensions of (a) extraversion, (b) openness, (c) emotional stability and (d) agreeableness. Moreover, the self-enhancing style of humor should also correlate positively with (e) positive affect (and negatively, with negative affect), with (f) life satisfaction and (g) subjective well-being.

H9- The aggressive style of humor should be negatively correlated with the dimensions of (a) consciousness and (b) agreeableness. This style of humor should also be negatively correlated with (c) life satisfaction and (d) well-being.

H10- The self-defeating style of humor should be negatively correlated to the dimensions of (a) emotional stability and (b) consciousness. In addition, negative correlations should also be observed between this style of humor and (c) life satisfaction and (d) well-being.

Temporal Validity:

H11- We expect to observe high levels of consistency (≥ .70), for all the four dimensions of the scale, between participants repeated responses to the HSQ, considering a two-week interval.

attributes.title: Humor at first sight: The role of positive humor in human-robot interaction in groups
attributes.description: Humor is a key aspect of social interactions that can enhance Human-Robot Interactions (HRI). We propose to explore how positive styles of humor (affiliative and self-enhancing) can influence HRI in groups, in terms of (a) robot perception, likability and acceptance; (b) user enjoyment; (c) intention to engage in future interactions. For this purpose, we will validate a set of jokes and test our research question using two card-game scenarios (Card Against Humanity (CAH) and Sueca). We expect participants to respond to the robot more positively in the condition in which it shows a congruent style of humor with that of the participant. We expect this effect to be stronger in the humorous task (CAH), than in the other task. We add to the literature by investigating the role of humor in HRI and creating a dataset of jokes that can foment more research and the development of better robots.
