The data collection process is expected to last between two and three months. Data collection will occur online, using the Qualtrics platform. Participants will receive a monetary compensation for the time invested in participating in this study.

Participants will be given an inform consent prior to the start of data collection and will be provided with a very general explanation about the study’s purpose (as not to influence their responses). To avoid order effects, both the items within each scale and the different scales used, will be presented randomly to participants, with the exception of the socio-demographic questionnaire, which will be presented last of all.

Participants will be provided a debriefing statement at the end of their participation and their participation on the second stage will be asked.

Data will be analyzed using IBM AMOS, v. 26 and IBM SPSS, V.26.  To analyze the pattern of missing values, a Little’s MCR (Missing Completely at Random) test will be conducted, and p-values >.05, will be considered an acceptable indicator that the data is not missing at random.

To assess the overall fit and the discrepancy between the sample and fitted covariance matrices, a Χ2/df test will be conducted; with p-values above 0.05 being considered sufficient to accept the null hypotheses. CFI (Comparative Fit Index) values ≥.95 will be accepted as indicative of good comparative model fit. RMSEA (Root Mean Square Error of Approximation) will be considered acceptable if <0.08; and Standardized Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR) will be considered acceptable if <.90. In addition, the Parsimony Normed Fit Index (PNFI) will be considered acceptable if it presents values < .60.

Moreover, we will also analyze the validity (convergent and discriminant) and the reliability of the model. In this context, AVE values >.5 will be considered as indicatives of good convergent validity; and if the √ AVE is > to the values of the inter-construct correlations, we will consider the items as having good discriminant validity.

For the initial CFA, a four-factor structure will be imposed, and items will be allowed to load only in to one category. Eigenvalues and loadings <.45 will be eliminating factors for items.

To test internal consistency, we will Cronbach Alpha’s and McDonald’s Omega. Values <0.5 will be considered unacceptable; values ≥ 0.5 and <0.7 will be considered poor-questionable. McDonald’s Omega’s values ≥ 0.7 and <0.8 will be considered acceptable; values ≥ 0.8 and <0.9. Values ≥ 0.9 will be considered excellent. 

Pearson coefficient will be used to calculate the correlations between scales, using similar standards for interpretation, as the ones described in the paragraph above.

To investigate criterion validity, stepwise multiple regression will be applied. In this context, we will enter each subscale of the No-Humor HSQ first, and then each corresponding sub-scale of the original HSQ.

Similarly, participants whose native tongue is not European Portuguese or whose ages is not between 18-45 will also be excluded from the analysis. Some of the participants’ data can also be excluded if it is not missing at random (see Missing Data section).

q23.value: Questionnaires with 50% or more of missing answers, will be excluded from the analysis. If the missing responses percentage is inferior to that value, a missing values’ analysis will be conducted. If the values are missing at random, they will be substituted using the expectation-maximization (EM) procedure. If the pattern of missing responses is not random, those participants will be excluded from the study.

registration_responses.q1: European Portuguese Validation of the Humor Styles Questionnaire.
registration_responses.q2: Raquel Oliveira, Patricia Arriaga, Ana Paiva
registration_responses.q3: Humor is an important social phenomenon that has been linked to several physical and psychological health benefits. In order to fully understand its importance, we need valid and reliable measures of humor. However, at this time, no such measures, translated and validated to European Portuguese, exist. Our goal with this study is to translate, validate and evaluate the psychometric properties of the Portuguese version of the Humor Styles Questionnaire (HSQ).
registration_responses.q4:
Factorial Structure and Internal Consistency:

H1- A confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) of the translated version of the HSQ should replicate the original factor structure, with each item loading only to one category and showing loadings ≥ .50 within its corresponding dimension and present a good-excellent level of model fit (see more information about the criteria used in the Data Analysis section of this pre-registration). 

H2- The four subscales of the HSQ will show acceptable internal consistency; 

Construct Validity:

H4- In all versions of the scale (i.e. HSQ, No Humor HSQ, Humor HSQ), high internal consistency is expected to be observed (≥ .80);

H5- We expect to observe higher levels of internal consistency in the Humor-HSQ, when compared to the No-Humor-HSQ, and to the HSQ;

H6- We expect to observe higher levels of correlation between the Humor-HSQ and the HSQ, than between any of the previous two and the No-Humor-HSQ, thereby suggesting that the non-humorous elements of the scale contribute little to explain construct relevant variance.

Criterion Validity:

H7- We expect to observe positive relations between the affiliative style of humor and the (a) extraversion and (b) openness dimensions of personality. In addition, this style of humor should also correlate (c) positively with positive affect (and negatively, with negative affect),  (d) with life satisfaction and (e) subjective well-being.

H8- A positive relation is expected between the self-enhancing style of personality and the dimensions of (a) extraversion, (b) openness, (c) emotional stability and (d) agreeableness. Moreover, the self-enhancing style of humor should also correlate positively with (e) positive affect (and negatively, with negative affect), with (f) life satisfaction and (g) subjective well-being.

H9- The aggressive style of humor should be negatively correlated with the dimensions of (a) consciousness and (b) agreeableness. This style of humor should also be negatively correlated with (c) life satisfaction and (d) well-being.

H10- The self-defeating style of humor should be negatively correlated to the dimensions of (a) emotional stability and (b) consciousness. In addition, negative correlations should also be observed between this style of humor and (c) life satisfaction and (d) well-being.

Temporal Validity:

H11- We expect to observe high levels of consistency (≥ .70), for all the four dimensions of the scale, between participants repeated responses to the HSQ, considering a two-week interval.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The goal of this study is to translate the HSQ to European Portuguese and evaluate the psychometric properties in terms of its structural characteristics, construct, criterion and temporal validity.

1.	Translation:

The translation of the HSQ will follow a pre-determined protocol. First, all of the items of the HSQ (as well, as the items from the No-Humor HSQ and the Humor HSQ; see Main Data Collection section below) will be independently translated to European Portuguese by two bilingual native speakers, expert in the field of Psychology. The resulting translations will then be combined by the first author and translated back to Portuguese by two bilingual individuals (English-Portuguese and vice-versa). The resulting translated items will be checked and adjusted for by the first author, if necessary, and a pilot-evaluation study with 10 individuals will be conducted, to assure the clarity of all of the items and corresponding instructions. These individuals will be asked to rate the questionnaires in terms of its clarity and understandability. If necessary, changes resulting from the feedback of these individuals will be implemented. The result of this process will then be considered the final version of the scale.

2.	Main Data Collection:
The main data collection will be run in two stages. In the first stage, participants will be requested to fill out an online questionnaire, which will be composed of the following instruments: (a) the translated version of HSQ (Martin, Phulik-Doris, Larsen, Gray & Weir, 2003); (b) the translated version of the No-Humor HSQ (Ruch & Heintz, 2017, adapted from Martin, Phulik-Doris, Larsen, Gray & Weir, 2003); (c) the translated version of the Humor-HSQ (Ruch & Heintz, 2017, adapted from Martin, Phulik-Doris, Larsen, Gray & Weir, 2003); (d) PANAS (Watson, Clark & Tellegen, 1988; Portuguese adaptation by Galinha & Pais-Ribeiro, 2005); (e) TIPI scale (Gosling, Rentfrow & Swann, 2003; adapted to Portuguese by Nunes, Limpo, Lima & Castro, 2018); (f) Personal Well-Being Scale (Cummins, McCabe, Romeo & Gullone, 1994; adapted to Portuguese by Ribeiro & Cummins, 2008) and (g) a brief socio-demographic questionnaire. Both the No-Humor HSQ and the Humor HSQ are scales derived from the original HSQ, adapted from the work of Ruch and Heintz (2017), and are intended to provide a way to measure the effect of the context-relevant and construct-relevant (respectively) elements of the original scale’s items in explaining its variance. The PANAS, TIPI and Personal Well-Being scales will be used to evaluate the scale’s criterion validity. In addition, two attention-check items will be included at random throughout the questionnaire, to guarantee that participants are paying attention.
The socio-demographic questionnaire will include questions regarding the participant’s (a) sex; (b) age; (c) native tongue; (d) nationality; (e) education and (f) level of attention while responding to the study.
Participation in this stage of the study is expected to last between 40 and 60 minutes.

3.	Repeated Measures:
In order to evaluate the HSQ temporal validity, subjects who participated in the main data collection stage, will be asked to respond to the items of the HSQ again, two weeks after they responded for the first time.
Participation in this stage of the study is expected to last, maximum, 15 minutes.

4.	Exploratory Analysis and Measures:
This study is included in a larger project, that aims at characterizing the role of positive humor in the acceptance and attitudes towards social robots. In this context, we will also ask participants to fill the NARS (Piçarra, Giger, Pochwatko & Gonçalves, 2015). Our goal with the introduction of this measure is to analyze the existence of potential correlations between specific styles of humor and participant’s perceptions of social robots.
